title: Accepting last-minute moon witnesses
vignette: Two travelers rush in just before nightfall claiming they saw the new moon. The court already prepared to keep the next day as the 30th. Should their testimony be accepted?

options.text: Accept and sanctify the new month now.
Ignore them; maintain the preset schedule.

title: Shofar on Shabbat
vignette: The first day of Rosh Hashanah falls on Shabbat. Some communities blow the shofar privately. May this be done?

options.text: No blowing on Shabbat at all.
Blow discreetly so the commandment isn't missed.

title: Interrupting prayer for shofar
vignette: During the silent Amidah a shofar blast is heard from outside. Should one pause to listen?

options.text: Pause briefly and listen.
Continue praying without interruption.

title: Bent vs. straight shofar
vignette: A community only has a straight antelope horn available. Traditionalists insist on a curved ram's horn. What should they do?

options.text: Use the available horn; fulfill the mitzvah.
Seek a curved horn even if it delays the service.

title: Women blowing shofar
vignette: Several women want to blow shofar themselves in synagogue. Some object that it is not obligatory for them.

options.text: Allow them; it inspires participation.
Discourage it; rely on the men's blasts.

title: Sending signal fires
vignette: The court debates whether to announce the new month by fires on mountain tops or by messengers only. Fires risk confusion from impostors.

options.text: Use fires for quick nationwide notice.
Rely solely on messengers to avoid mistakes.

title: False moon testimony
vignette: Witnesses are found to have lied about seeing the moon. Should they be punished publicly to deter others?

options.text: Yes; make an example of them.
No; quietly reject their testimony only.

title: Blowing shofar for the king
vignette: A foreign monarch visiting Jerusalem requests a special shofar salute on Rosh Hashanah. Complying may show honour but also mix secular motives with the ritual.

options.text: Agree and blow as a gesture of respect.
Decline; the blasts are solely for worship.

title: Sanctifying the month at night
vignette: Witnesses arrive after dark. Traditionally sanctification is by day. May the court declare the new month that night?

options.text: Wait until morning despite the delay.
Sanctify immediately by torchlight.

title: Partial year as a full year
vignette: A king ascends the throne in Adar. When counting reign years for contracts, is the coming Nisan already considered year two?

options.text: Yes; a partial year counts as a whole.
No; start counting only after twelve full months.

title: Changing the prayer order
vignette: The cantor wants to insert extra melodies between the shofar blasts and their accompanying blessings. Some object to altering tradition.

options.text: Allow creative melodies for inspiration.
Stick to the established order.

title: Children hearing shofar
vignette: Young kids run around noisily during the shofar service. Some wonder if it's worth bringing them at all since they don't listen attentively.

options.text: Bring them to accustom them early.
Leave them home to maintain decorum.

title: Minimum number of blasts
vignette: A small congregation only manages to blow a simple set of ten blasts instead of the usual series. Is the obligation fulfilled?

options.text: Yes; any coherent series suffices.
No; the full quota of blasts is required.

title: Traveling far to testify
vignette: Witnesses from a distant village will miss Rosh Hashanah at home if they travel to Jerusalem to testify about the moon. Should they go?

options.text: Yes; sanctifying the calendar is paramount.
Stay home and celebrate locally.

title: Blowing shofar after musaf
vignette: Some propose delaying the shofar blasts until after the lengthy musaf service to draw a bigger crowd. Others insist on blowing earlier.

options.text: Blow early during the service as usual.
Delay to maximise attendance.
